ordinances of the city of laurinburg north carolina source materials used in the preparation of the the 1987 as supplemented  and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1987 as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 62 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes charter cht1 charter comparative table chtct1 code cd code appendix cda1 code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 charter index chti1 code index cdi1 indexes the indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept uptodate subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication uptodate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and municipal charters gs 160a101160a110 chapter i  incorporation and corporate powers incorporation and corporate powers the inhabitants of the city of laurinburg are a body corporate and politic under the name of the city of laurinburg under that name they have all the powers duties rights privileges and immunities conferred and imposed on cities by the general law of north carolina chapter ii  corporate boundaries city boundaries the boundaries of the city of laurinburg are set out on a map entitled boundary map of the city of laurinburg north carolina the map is maintained in the office of the city clerk as required by gs 160a22 editors note the city boundaries have changed due to annexations made since the effective date of the charter chapter iii  governing body structure of governing body  number of members the governing body of the city of laurinburg is the city council which has five members and a mayor manner of election of council two 2 of the five 5 city councilmembers shall be elected from district 1 two 2 from district 2 and one 1 from the city at large to be eligible to be a candidate for and to hold one of the council seats representing a district a person must reside in that district only voters who reside in a district shall be eligible to vote for the councilmembers representing that district all voters in the city may vote for the at large member sess laws 199 ch 65 term of office of members of the city council a in the regular city election in 1995 three 3 councilmembers shall be elected two 2 from district 1 and one 1 from district 2 all candidates for the two 2 seats from district 1 shall be listed together on the ballot and each voter shall be allowed to cast up to two 2 votes the candidate for district 1 receiving the most votes shall be elected for a term to expire in 199 and the candidate receiving the next highest number of votes shall be elected for a term to expire in 1997 the councilmember elected in 1995 from district 2 shall be elected for a term to expire in 1999 b in 1997 and every two 2 years thereafter three 3 councilmembers shall be elected one 1 from district 1 one 1 from district 2 and one 1 at large the councilmembers elected from districts 1 and 2 shall be elected for fouryear terms and the member elected at large shall be elected for a fouryear term beginning with the 2001 election sess laws 199 ch 65   election of mayor  term of office  voting rights the qualified voters of the entire city shall elect the mayor he is elected to a fouryear term of office beginning with the 2003 election the mayor shall not vote on any question before the council except in case of a tie vote deadlocking a decision of the council  council election districts reserved sess laws 199 ch 65 editors note the two 2 districts for the election of members of the city council shall be as approved by the us department of justice per resolution r200129 adopted on  chapter iv  elections footnotes  2  state law general provisions designation and citation of ordinances embraced in this and the following sections shall constitute and be designated the ordinances city of laurinburg north carolina and may be so cited such ordinances may also be cited as the laurinburg city   definitions and rules of construction in the construction of this all ordinances the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise acts by agents when any provision of this an act to be done which may by law as well be done by an agent as by the principal such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent bond when a bond is required an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient charter the term charter shall mean and refer to the charter of the city of laurinburg as printed in part i of this volume city the term the city shall mean the city of laurinburg in the county of scotland and the state of north carolina and shall extend to and include its various officers agents and employees when acting within the scope of their employment except as otherwise provided city council the term city council shall mean the city council of the city of laurinburg term  means the ordinances city of laurinburg north carolina as designated in section 11 computation of time in computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by this the day of the act event default or publication after which the designated period of time begins to run is not to be included the last day of the period so computed is to be included unless it is a saturday sunday or legal holiday in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a saturday sunday or legal holiday when the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven days intermediate saturdays sundays and holidays shall be excluded in the computation a half holiday shall be considered as other days and not as a holiday county the term the county shall mean the county of scotland in the state of north carolina except as otherwise provided gender terms importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter general statutes gs the term general statutes or the abbreviation gs shall mean the latest edition of the general statutes of north carolina as amended interpretation in the interpretation and application of any provision it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health safety comfort convenience and general welfare where any provision imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by this the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be controlling joint authority all terms giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers may the term may is always directory and not mandatory month the term month shall mean a calendar month nontechnical and technical terms all terms and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language but technical terms and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning number terms used in the singular include the plural and the plural includes the singular number oath the term oath shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the terms swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the terms affirm and affirmed officers departments boards commissions and other agencies references to the city manager city clerk chief of police or other officers any department board commission or any other agency unless otherwise indicated shall be construed as if followed by the term of the city of laurinburg official time standard whenever certain hours are named in this they shall mean eastern standard time or eastern daylight saving time whichever may be in current use in the city or and the term or may be read and and the term and may be read or where the sense requires it owner the term owner applied to any property shall include any part owner joint owner tenant in common joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such property person  the term person shall include a corporation firm partnership association organization and any other group acting as a unit as well as an individual personal property the term personal property shall include moneys goods chattels chooses in action and evidences of debt including all things capable of ownership not descendible to heirs at law preceding following the terms preceding and following shall mean next before and next after respectively property the term property shall include real and personal property as defined in this section real property the term real property shall include lands tenements and hereditaments references to chapters or sections all references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this unless otherwise specified shall the term shall is always mandatory and not directory sidewalk the term sidewalk shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians signature subscription the terms signature and subscription shall include a mark when the person cannot write state the term the state shall mean the state of north carolina street the term street shall include avenues boulevards highways roads alleys lanes viaducts bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city and shall mean the entire width thereof between abutting property lines tenant and occupant  the terms tenant and occupant when applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land whether alone or with others tense terms used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well as the past and present tense shall include the future as well as the past and present when applicable week the term week shall be construed to mean seven days but publication in the newspaper or any notice or other matter indicated to be for a stated number of weeks shall be construed to mean one insertion in each week unless specifically stated to be for each day of the week or for more than one day in each week writing written the terms writing and written shall include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters year the term year shall mean a calendar year  state law reference rules of construction gs 123  citation of general statutes gs 1641 other headings a the catchlines of the several sections of this in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of the section nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections including the catchlines are amended or reenacted b the history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section cross references and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this have no legal effect  provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances the provisions appearing in this so far as they are the same or substantially the same as those of the 1987 all ordinances adopted subsequent to the 1987 included in this be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments  effect of repeal or expiration of ordinance the repeal of an ordinance or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein shall not affect any right accrued any offense committed any penalty or punishment incurred or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired when any ordinance which repealed another shall itself be repealed the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect  state law reference similar provisions applicable to state laws gs 122 certain ordinances not affected by in this the ordinance adopting this affect any of the following when not inconsistent herewith 1 any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the citys indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city  2 any annual tax levy appropriation or budget  3 any right or franchise conferred by ordinance on any person or corporation  4 any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated  5 any ordinance which is temporary although general in effect or special although permanent in effect  6 any ordinance relating to the salaries of the city officers or employees  7 any ordinance annexing territory to the city  8 any ordinance naming renaming opening accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city  9 any ordinance pertaining to traffic or parking regulations applying to specific streets  10 any ordinance setting fees charges or rates for city services  and all such ordinances shall remain in full force and effect as if set out at length in this  state law reference authority supplementation of a by contract or by city personnel supplements to this be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council a supplement to the include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the shall also include all amendments to the charter during that period the pages of a supplement shall be numbered so that they will fit properly into the will where necessary replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete and the new pages shall be prepared so that when they have been inserted the be current date of the adoption of the latest ordinances included in the supplement b in preparing a supplement to this all portions of the have been repealed shall be excluded from the the omission thereof from reprinted pages c when preparing a supplement to this the codifier meaning the person agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code for example the codifier may 1 organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions  2 provide appropriate catchlines headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines headings and titles  3 assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the where necessary to accommodate new material change existing section or other subdivision numbers  4 change the term this ordinance or terms of the same meaning to this chapter this article this division etc as the case may be or to sections _____ to _____ inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the   and 5 make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the  general penalty  enforcement provisions  remedies available to city to rectify violations  continuing violations a wherever in this in any ordinance of the city or in any rule regulation order or notice of any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or it any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or whether in such ordinance rule regulation order or notice the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor where no specific penalty is provided the violation of any such provision of this any such ordinance rule regulation order or notice shall be a misdemeanor as provided in gs 144 and shall subject each such violator to the punishment provided in such section b pursuant to the authority of gs 160a175 the city may secure injunctions and abatement orders to further ensure compliance with this other city ordinances as provided by this section c any provision of this other ordinance of the city for the enforcement of which an appropriate remedy in equity exists may be enforced by an appropriate equitable remedy issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction in such case the general court of justice has jurisdiction under gs 160a175 to issue such orders as may be appropriate and it is declared by that section that it shall not be a defense to the application of the city for such equitable relief that there is an adequate remedy at law d when a violation of any provision of this other ordinance occurs which makes unlawful a condition existing upon or use made of real property the city may pursuant to the authority of gs 160a175 apply to the appropriate division of the general court of justice for a mandatory or prohibitory injunction and order of abatement commanding the defendant to correct the unlawful condition upon or cease the unlawful use of the property the action shall be governed in all respects by the laws and rules governing civil proceedings including the rules of civil procedure in general and rule 65 in particular as required by gs 160a175 e subject to the express terms thereof any portion of this any other ordinance of the city may be enforced by any one all or a combination of the remedies prescribed by this section and gs 160a175 f unless otherwise provided each days continuing violation of any provision of this other ordinance shall be a separate and distinct offense  state law reference violation of local ordinance human relations ch 20  law enforcement ch 22  public records ch 26  taxation ch 34  utilities ch 40 state law reference cities and towns gs ch 160a article i  in general disposing of personal property a pursuant to gs 160a266c the city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to dispose of any surplus personal property owned by the city whenever the city manager or designee determines in his discretion that 1 the item or group of items has a fair market value of less than $3000000  2 the property is no longer necessary for the conduct of public business  and 3 sound property management principles and financial considerations indicate that the interests of the city would best be served by disposing of the property b the city manager or designee may dispose of any such surplus personal property by any means which he judges reasonably calculated to yield the highest attainable sale price in money or other consideration including but not limited to the methods of sale provided in gs ch 160a art 12 such sale may be public or private and with or without notice and a minimum waiting period c the surplus property shall be sold to the party who tenders the highest offer or exchanged for any property or services useful to the city if greater value may be obtained in that manner and the city manager or designee is hereby authorized to execute and deliver any applicable title documents if no offers are received within a reasonable time the city manager or designee may retain the property obtain any reasonably available salvage value or cause the property to be disposed of as waste material no surplus property may be donated to any individual or organization except by resolution of the city council d the city manager or designee shall keep a record of all property sold under authority of this section and such record shall generally describe the property sold or exchanged to whom it was sold or with whom exchanges were made and the amount of money or other considerations received for each sale or exchange e the city manager or designee shall submit a report to the city council on a semiannual basis listing all items sold under the provisions of this section the person to whom the items were sold and the amount of each sale items sold between january 1 and june 30 shall be reported at the regular council meeting in july items sold between july 1 and december 31 shall be reported at the regular council meeting in january    4162013 state law reference power to dispose of property gs 160a11 purchase orders before any order is given for items to be purchased for the city by any city officer or employee a purchase order must first be obtained from the city manager  state law reference regulation of contracts gs  160a16 et seq policies to be as prescribed by the city council and agreed upon by the insurers b nothing in this section shall be construed as a waiver by the city of its governmental immunity beyond the extent of the amount and type of any insurance coverage obtained by the city pursuant to subsection a of this section and which is in effect at the time of any claim  state law reference waiver of immunity account to which the payment was credited  and the city treasurer shall give his receipt for each payment received by him all city funds so received shall be deposited by the city treasurer in a fidelity bonds for each officer employee or agent who handles or has in his custody more than $10000 of the citys at any time or who handles or has access to the citys inventories gs 15929 public officials and employees code of conduct a it is the obligation of every public official and employee to support the constitution of the united states and the constitution of the state b the laws of the nation state and city shall be impartially administered no public official or employee shall grant any special consideration treatment or advantage to any citizen beyond that which is available to every other citizen except by due process of law c every citizen shall receive a fair and impartial hearing on any matter coming before the city council its appointed agencies or any employee of the city no public official or employee shall make any promise or pledge to any person concerning any matter to be heard before such public official or employee except upon fair impartial and final hearing thereof d the conduct of public business shall be free of any hidden personal or financial interest of any public official or employee no public official or employee shall advocate in any public meeting or private discussion incident thereto any matter in which he has a personal or financial interest except upon full and timely disclosure of such interest e it is the obligation of every public official to faithfully discharge the duties of his office in the conduct of public business no public official shall be excused from voting except on matters involving consideration of his own official conduct or where his financial interests are involved every public official shall make a full and timely disclosure of any personal or financial interest which he has in any matter of public business to be transacted before him f the conduct of public business shall be free of any influence arising from gifts favors or special privileges it is the obligation of every public official and employee to refuse personal gifts favors or special privileges in every instance where such public official or employee reasonably believes such gift favor or special privilege would not have been extended but for the position of such public official or employee or where there exists a reasonable belief that the givers interest is likely to be affected by the actions of such public official or employee or where the gift is or may reasonably be considered to be designed to influence the actions of such public official or employee no public official or employee shall seek personal or financial advantage by means of his public office appointment or employment g the use of public trust for private gain is inimical to good government no public official or employee shall violate the provision of gs 14234 no public official or employee shall use confidential or advance information obtained by virtue of public office appointment or employment for personal or financial advantage h no public official employee officer or agent of the city shall participate in selection or in the award or administration of a contract supported by federal funds if a conflict of interest real or apparent would be involved no employee officer or agent any member of his immediate family his partner or an organization which employs or is about to employ any of such persons shall have a financial or other interest in the firm selected for such award i the citys officers employees or agents shall neither solicit nor accept gratuities favors or anything of monetary value from contractors potential contractors or parties to subagreements j it is the obligation of every public official and employee to carry out the lawful orders and policies of the city council no public official or employee shall knowingly take any action inconsistent with the lawful orders or policies established by the city council no public official or employee shall knowingly take any action which would be detrimental to the best interests of the city  secs 2792110  reserved article iv  boards and commissions footnotes  4  cross reference city tree committee  4261 et seq state law reference authority to et seq  public airports and related facilities gs 6349 et seq definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning airport means the laurinburgmaxton airport airport commission means the laurinburgmaxton airport commission as created in section 2132  cross reference definitions generally  12 created there is hereby created an airport commission to be known as the laurinburgmaxton airport commission  composition the airport commission shall be composed of six members  election of members the governing body of the town of maxton and the city council of the city of laurinburg shall each elect three members to the airport commission  qualification of members members of the airport commission shall be residents respectively of the town of maxton and the city  term of members the initial members of the airport commission shall serve staggered terms thereafter each member appointed by the city council of the city of laurinburg shall serve a threeyear term  filling of vacancies any vacancy that shall occur in the membership of the airport commission caused by death resignation or inability to serve shall be filled by the governing body of the town of maxton or the city council of the city of laurinburg depending on where the vacating airport commission member was a resident at the time the vacancy occurred  compensation of members each member of the airport commission including the secretarytreasurer and the chairperson shall receive such compensation as the governing body of the town of maxton and the city council of the city of laurinburg shall designate commensurate with the duties and requirements of their offices  chairperson the chairperson of the airport commission shall alternate between members appointed by the city and the members appointed by the town of maxton if the chairperson as previously elected by the airport commission is not eligible for reelection to the chairmanship either by reason of having served two successive oneyear terms or by reason of not having been reappointed to the airport commission the chairmanship shall automatically rotate so that the chairperson shall be elected from the members appointed by the municipality from which the retiring chairperson was not appointed such chairperson shall have no voting privilege except in case of a tie  attorney and auditor at the regularly scheduled meeting of the airport commission in june of each year the airport commission shall elect an attorney to advise and represent the airport commission and an auditor to advise and assist the airport commission for the next ensuing fiscal year extending from july 1 of the then current year to the next following june 30  action by majority vote  quorum the actions of the airport commission shall be determined by a majority vote of the members of the airport commission and a majority of such members shall constitute a quorum for any meeting of the airport commission  duties generally the airport commission shall establish improve maintain equip operate and regulate all airports navigation facilities and all other real and personal property owned or acquired by the city and the town of maxton for the use and benefit of the airport  exercise of powers generally on behalf of the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg the airport commission may exercise all powers of each municipality granted by gs ch 63 except as provided in such chapter or as otherwise limited by the agreement between the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg entered into for the purpose of operating the airport property  responsibility  special duties and special reports the airport commission shall at all times be responsible to the governing body of the town of maxton and the city council of the city of laurinburg and shall perform any special duties or make any special reports requested of the airport commission  sale and lease of real property no real property nor airport or other navigation facility owned jointly by the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg shall be disposed of by the airport commission by sale or otherwise except by authority of the governing body of the town of maxton and the city council of the city of laurinburg the airport commission may lease personal property space area land or improvements and grant concessions at the airport for aeronautical purposes or purposes incidental thereto or for other purposes wherein the revenue is to be used for airport purposes except that no such agreements shall be contrary to the existing joint agreement between the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg for the operation of such facilities or any conditions or restrictions placed upon such property as a condition upon which it was obtained from the united states or the state relating thereto  control of revenues and expenditures the airport commission shall have full control of all revenues received by reason of the airport or other aeronautical facilities and shall have power to expend all sums for such aeronautical purposes as the airport commission deems proper and to pay over any surplus to the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg in proportion to their respective interests  except however that such right may be limited by any restrictions or agreements whereby any of the property owned or controlled by the airport commission was obtained  fund established for the purpose of providing funds for the necessary expenditures in carrying out the provisions of this division the airport commission shall establish an airport commission fund into which the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg shall deposit its proportionate share as provided by the joint agreement adopted by the two municipalities for the operation of the airport facilities and into which shall be paid all revenues obtained from the ownership control and operation of the airport and other air navigation facilities jointly owned by the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg and controlled by the airport commission  disbursements of funds a all disbursements from the airport commission fund established in section 2147 shall be made by order of the airport commission  subject however to such limitations as shall be contained in the agreement adopted by the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg for the operation of the airport facilities b all funds under the control of the airport commission shall be disbursed only upon the signature of the chairperson and one airport commission member or the chairperson or vicechairperson and the duly appointed fiscal agent of the airport commission  determination and approval of total annual expenditures the total amount of expenditures to be made by the airport commission for any purpose in any calendar year shall be determined and approved by both the governing body of the town of maxton and the city council of the city of laurinburg  annual report and budget at least annually the airport commission shall make a report to the governing body of the town of maxton and the city council of the city of laurinburg giving information regarding the condition of the airport facilities and other property owned by the two municipalities included in this report shall be a budget adopted by the airport commission setting forth the anticipated revenue and expenditures of the airport commission in the administration of its duties for the forthcoming year such report shall be made not later than the date fixed by the laws of the state for the adoption of annual budgets by municipalities as provided in the general statutes  annual inventory the airport commission shall annually take and keep an inventory of all property jointly owned by the town of maxton and the city of laurinburg which has been under the control and supervision of the airport commission  secs 21522155  reserved division 3  historic preservation commission footnotes  6  editors note  adopted oct 24 200 added provisions that were not specifically amendatory at the editors discretion said provisions have been included herein as  21562164 cross reference buildings and building regulations ch 6 creation and appointment the city council hereby establishes by authority of of the north carolina general statutes a historic preservation commission the commission shall consist of at least five members appointed by the city council a majority of its members must reside within the city of laurinburg at its discretion the council may appoint members who reside within the citys extraterritorial planning jurisdiction a majority of the members of the commission shall have demonstrated special interest experience or education in history architecture archaeology or related fields members of the commission shall serve terms of four years and shall be appointed or reappointed according to the policies of the city council terms of the initial appointments shall be set in such a way as to have staggered terms on the commission 1 10242006 rules of procedure the commission shall adopt rules of procedure necessary to the conduct of its affairs and in keeping with the provisions of this division the rules of procedure adopted by the commission shall at least provide for the following 1 the selection of officers  2 the time and place of regular meetings and the calling of special meetings  3 the procedures for the conduct of public hearings  4 the conduct of voting  and 5 the forms to be used in applying for or denying certificates of appropriateness for changes to historic landmarks designated by the city council 2 10242006 powers and duties of the commission the powers and duties of the commission are as follows 1 undertake inventories of properties of historical prehistorical architectural andor cultural significance  2 recommend to the city council structures buildings sites areas or objects to be designated by ordinance as historic landmarks  3 recommend to the city council that designation of any historic landmark be revoked for cause  4 review and act upon proposals for the alteration or demolition of any historic landmark  5 enter solely in the performance of its official duties and only at reasonable times upon private lands for the examination or survey thereof  however no member employee or agent of the commission may enter any private building or structure without express consent of the owner or occupant thereof 6 restore preserve and operate historic properties  7 acquire by lawful means the fee or lesser included interest including options to purchase to properties designated as historic landmarks to hold manage preserve restore and improve the same and to exchange or dispose of the property by public or private sale lease or otherwise subject covenants or other legally binding restrictions which will secure appropriate rights of public access and promote the preservation of the property  8 conduct education programs with respect to historic districts and landmarks within the city  9 cooperate with state federal and local government in furthering the purposes of this division  to request and offer assistance aid guidance or advice concerning matters under its purview or of mutual interest  10 negotiate at any time with the owner of a building structure site area or object for its acquisition or its preservation when such action is deemed reasonably necessary or appropriate 11 prepare and recommend the official adoption of a preservation element as part of the municipalitys comprehensive plan 3 10242006 adoption of an ordinance of designation upon complying with the required landmark designation procedures set forth in this division the city council may adopt and from time to time amend or repeal an ordinance designating one or more historic landmarks no property shall be recommended by the commission for designation as a landmark unless it is deemed to be f special significance in terms of its historical prehistorical architectural or cultural importance and to possess integrity of design setting workmanship materials feeling andor association the ordinance shall include the following information 1 description of each property designated in the ordinance  2 list of the names of the owner or owners  3 description of the elements of the property that are integral to its historical architectural or historical value  and 4 provision for an appropriate sign to be placed on the property indicating that the property is designated as a historic landmark 1 10242006 guidelines for historic landmarks the commission shall use the inventory or inventories of historic properties in the city of laurinburg the historic districts listed on the national register of historic places individual nominations for listing on the national register and other local resources as a guides for recommending designation of historic landmarks within the resources available to it the commission may update the citys inventories 2 10242006 required procedures for designation a designation report the commission shall prepare or review an investigation and report describing the significance of the buildings structures features sites or surroundings proposed for designation or other action by the commission for purposes of this division a property should meet one of the following criteria in order to have special significance 1 it is associated with events that have contributed significantly to the history of laurinburg or a wider region 2 it is associated with the life of a person who is significant in laurinburgs past or the past of the region state or nation 3 it embodies the distinctive characteristics of a type period or method of construction 4 it represents the work of a master or possesses high artistic values 5 it has yielded or is likely to yield important historical or prehistorical information the designation report shall be submitted to the north carolina department of cultural resources the department acting state historic preservation officer shall be given an opportunity to review and comment upon the substance of the report and the effect of designation of the property as a landmark if the department does not respond within 30 days of receipt of the report the commission is relieved of any responsibility to consider such comments the commission at its discretion may refer the report to other local groups for comment before it is finalized b public hearing after the report is finalized and the designation ordinance is prepared the commission and the city council shall hold public hearings prior to adoption of the ordinance a joint public hearing may be held the public hearings may only be held after public notice is given in the same manner as for adoption or amendment of the zoning ordinance c adoption following the public hearing and receiving a recommendation from the commission the city council may adopt the designation ordinance along with any amendments it deems appropriate or reject the ordinance amendments to any designation ordinance shall follow the same steps as required for adopting the ordinance 3 10242006 certificate of appropriateness a requirement from and after designation of a historic landmark no exterior portion of any building or other structure including masonry walls fences light fixtures steps and pavement or other appurtenant features nor aboveground utility structure nor any type of outdoor advertising sign shall be erected altered restored moved or demolished on such landmark until after an application for a certificate of appropriateness as to exterior features has been submitted to and approved by the commission no permit for such work shall be issued until the commission approves the certificate of appropriateness the certificate of appropriateness for such work is required whether or not a building permit or other permit is required as specified in gs 160a4009f the requirement for a certificate of appropriateness is applicable to construction alteration moving and demolition by the state of north carolina its political subdivisions agencies and instrumentalities provided however they shall not apply to interiors of buildings or structures owned by the state of north carolina the state and its agencies shall have a right of appeal to the north carolina historical commission or any successor agency assuming its responsibilities under gs 12112a from any decision of the commission the decision of the commission shall be final and binding upon both the state and the commission this requirement for a certificate of appropriateness shall be a part of any ordinance designating a historic landmark b review guidelines prior to the designation of any local historic landmarks the commission shall prepare and adopt guidelines not inconsistent with of of the north carolina general statutes for altering restoring moving or demolishing property designated as landmarks these guidelines shall ensure insofar as possible that changes in designated landmarks are in harmony with the special character of the landmark c certain changes not prohibited nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent the ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature of a designated landmark that does not involve a change in design materials or outer appearance thereof  the ordinary maintenance or repair of streets sidewalks pavement markings street signs or traffic signs  the construction reconstruction alteration restoration or demolition of any such feature that the building inspector shall certify is required by the public safety because of an unsafe or dangerous condition nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent the maintenance or in the event of an emergency the immediate restoration of any existing aboveground utility structure without approval of the commission d minor works after adoption of detailed standards by the preservation commission of detailed standards the building inspector may review and approve applications for a certificate of appropriateness or of minor works as defined specified in the standards e appeals an appeal may be taken to the board of adjustment from the commissions action in granting or denying any certificate which appeals 1 may be taken by any aggrieved party 2 shall be taken within times prescribed by the historic preservation commission by general rule and 3 shall be in the nature of certiorari any appeal from the board of adjustments decision in any such case shall be heard by the superior court of the county in which the municipality is located  10242006 enforcement and remedies the city building inspector shall enforce compliance with the terms of the certificate of appropriateness failure to comply with the certificate shall be a violation that is punishable in the same manner as a violation of the unified development case any landmark is about to be demolished whether as a result of deliberate neglect or otherwise materially altered remodeled removed or destroyed except in compliance with this division the commission the city council or any other aggrieved party may institute any action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful action  10242006 demolition delay a an application for a certificate of appropriateness authorizing demolition removal or destruction of a landmark may not be denied except as provided in subsection 2164c however the effective date of such a certificate may be delayed up to 365 days from the date of approval the period of delay may be reduced if the commission finds that the owner would suffer extreme hardship or be permanently deprived of all beneficial use or return from such property by virtue of the delay if the commission has voted to recommend designation of a property as a landmark and final designation has not been made by the city council the demolition or destruction of any building site or structure located on the property of the proposed landmark or in the proposed district may be delayed by the commission for a period of up to 180 days or until the city council takes final action on the designation whichever occurs first b the city council may enact an ordinance to prevent the demolition by neglect of any designated landmark such ordinance shall provide appropriate safeguards to protect property owners from undue hardship c an application for a certificate of appropriateness authorizing the demolition of a designated landmark determined by the state historic preservation officer as having statewide significance as defined in the criteria of the national register of historic places may be denied except where the commission finds that the owner would suffer extreme hardship or be permanently deprived of all beneficial use or return from such property by virtue of the denial  10242006 secs 21652180  reserved article v  extraterritorial jurisdiction footnotes  7 reference environment ch 16  pushcarts bicycles and animals  385 state law reference dogs generally gs ch 67  rabies control gs 130a184 et seq  regulation of domestic animals gs 160a186  regulation of dangerous animals gs 160a187 article i  in general definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning animal means every living creature domestic or nondomestic but not including humans animal shelter means any premises provided and operated for the restraint care and disposition of animals whether such shelter is public or private in nature at large means an animal off the property of its owner or keeper and not under physical restraint  however such term shall not be construed to include any cat cat means both male and female cats of any age commercial animal establishment means any pet shop grooming shop auction riding school or stable zoological park circus animal exhibition or kennel dangerous dog means a dog that 1 has killed or inflicted severe injury on a person without provocation  2 is determined by the person designated by the city manager to be potentially dangerous because the dog has engaged in one or more of the behaviors listed in the definition in this section of the term potentially dangerous dog  and 3 is owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting dog means both male and female dogs of any age domestic means any animal kept cared for sheltered fed or harbored as a pet for work purposes or as a source of food raw materials or income head of household means the person who maintains the household impounded means having been taken or received into the custody of the animal control officer or any authorized representative thereof keeper means a person having custody of an animal or who keeps or harbors an animal or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied or controlled by such person nondomestic means any animal that is wild or dangerous by natural existence nuisance means an animal or group of animals if it 1 damages soils or defiles private or public property  2 interferes with molests or attacks persons or other animals  3 causes unsanitary dangerous or offensive conditions including fouling of the air by odors  4 by virtue of number or type is offensive or dangerous to the public health safety or welfare  5 is diseased or dangerous to the public health  6 habitually or repeatedly makes noises or other sounds that tend to annoy disturb or frighten citizens owner means any person owning keeping or harboring any dog or cat for the purpose of this chapter the head of the household shall be deemed to be the owner in respect to any dog or cat owned kept or harbored by any person residing in such household and kept on the premises owners real property means any real property owned or leased by the owners of any dog or cat but does not include any public rightofway or a common area of a condominium apartment complex or townhouse development potentially dangerous dog means a dog that the person designated by the city manager determines to have 1 inflicted a bite on a person that resulted in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations or required cosmetic surgery or hospitalization  2 killed or inflicted severe injury upon a domestic animal when not on the owners real property  or 3 approached a person in a vicious or terrorizing manner in an apparent attitude of attack when not on the owners real property restraint means any animal if it is within the real property limits of its owner or secured by a leash or lead or confined severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations or requires cosmetic surgery or hospitalization stray means any domestic animal not under restraint and found off the property of its owner or keeper vicious animal means an animal that constitutes a physical threat to humans or other domestic animals  cross reference definitions generally  12 authority to appoint animal control officers authority is hereby given to the city manager in his discretion to appoint one or more animal control officers  animal control officers responsibilities  right of investigation and inspection a the employees of the animal control program shall 1 enforce and carry out all laws of the state and all ordinances of the city pertaining to animals  2 be empowered to issue notices of violations of this chapter in such form as the city council may prescribe b whenever it is necessary to make an investigation or inspection to enforce any of the provisions of or perform any duty imposed by this chapter or other applicable law or whenever the animal control officer or his designated agent has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any violation of the provisions of this chapter or other applicable law the animal control officer or his designated agent is hereby empowered to enter such property at any reasonable time and to inspect the property and perform any duty imposed upon such animal control officer or his agent by this chapter or other applicable law  44 interference with enforcement it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with hinder or molest the animal control officer or persons duly authorized by this chapter or to seek to release any animal in the custody of such person except as otherwise specifically provided  animals at large it shall be unlawful for any person owning or having possession charge custody or control of any animal to suffer permit or allow the animal to stray or in any manner to run at large in or upon any public street sidewalk or park or upon the property of another if such animal is not under sufficient physical restraint to allow the animal to be controlled  state law reference authority of city by ordinance to regulate restrict or prohibit the keeping or running at large of domestic animals gs 160a186 creating and maintaining nuisances it shall be unlawful for an owner or keeper to permit an animal to create a nuisance or to maintain a nuisance created by an animal  cross reference nuisances  1631 et seq collecting dogs and cats for resale it shall be unlawful for any person to collect any dog or cat for the purpose of resale within the corporate limits of the city by soliciting from house to house setting traps or other means on any land within the city  keeping livestock it shall be unlawful for any person to keep maintain harbor pasture or stable cows horses mules and other livestock within the corporate limits of the city within 150 feet of any residence school church or commercial or public eating place but such prohibition shall not apply to the keeping of swine or goats  keeping swine goats chickens or domesticated ducks it shall be unlawful for any person to keep any pigs hogs goats chickens or domesticated ducks within the corporate limits of the city    10242006 editors note of states that this section shall be in full force on and after nov 1 2006 keeping fowl all yards premises sheds coops etc occupied by chickens or other fowl shall be deemed a nuisance if not cleaned regularly and kept in a sanitary condition at all times  keeping nondomestic animals no person shall possess or harbor any nondomestic animal which is dangerous to persons or property or which has the potential of being dangerous to persons or property this section shall not apply to bona fide circuses petting zoos and other traveling commercial animal exhibitions of limited duration  bird sanctuary established all of the territory within the territorial limits of the city shall be a bird sanctuary  state law reference declaring wild animal or bird a pest gs 1133002  authorizing government body of municipality to create and establish a bird sanctuary within territorial limit of municipality gs 160a188 hunting killing and trapping it shall be unlawful for any person to hunt kill or trap any animal within the territorial limits of the city this section shall not apply to the animal control officer or duly authorized agent when enforcing the provisions provided in this chapter  slaughterhouses and butchering it shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated any slaughterhouse or to do any butchering within the city  compliance with state dangerous dog laws required  article supplemental to dangerous dog laws  additional regulations a it shall be unlawful for any animal owner or other person to fail to comply with the state laws relating to dangerous dogs b it is the purpose of this chapter to supplement the state laws by providing a procedure for the enforcement of state laws relating to dangerous dogs in addition to the criminal penalties provided by state law c the city manager shall designate a person to be responsible for determining when a dog is a dangerous dog and shall designate a separate board to hear any appeals d in addition to complying with the state laws owners of animals determined to be dangerous shall observe the following 1 the owner shall meet all requirements for licensing and rabies inoculations  2 a dangerous dog shall wear an identifying collar as provided by the city at the owners expense  3 a dangerous dog shall be sterilized or neutered such altering may be performed by any veterinarian licensed to practice in the state of north carolina and shall be performed within 20 days after the date the dog meets the definition of a dangerous dog all fees shall be paid in full by the owner to the satisfaction of the veterinarian prior to release 4 while on the owners property a dangerous dog must be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or kennel suitable to prevent entry or reaching young children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping the pen or kennel may not share common fencing with an area or perimeter fence the kennel or pen must have secure sides at least six feet in height  a secure top attached to all sides  the sides must be either buried two feet into the ground sunken into a concrete pad or securely attached to a wire bottom the gate to the kennel must be locked the enclosure must also provide protection from the elements for the animal and have a ground area of at least five feet by 20 feet the owner or keeper shall display a sign on his premises warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property the sign shall be visible and capable of being read from the public highway 5 the owner or keeper must allow officers of the animal control department to make whatever inquiries are deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this subsection d including inspection of the owners or keepers premises where the dangerous dog is confined if an inspection reveals that the owner or keeper has not complied with the requirements for confining a dangerous dog animal control shall issue a $10000 civil penalty and may impound the dog at the animal shelter if the dog shall be impounded and shall not be redeemed within five working days and the owner shall not request an appeal within the time limit provided the dog shall be deemed abandoned and shall be disposed of in accordance with this chapter 6 if a dangerous dog escapes its confinement or frees itself from its owner or keeper an animal control officer or other law enforcement officer is authorized to destroy the dog on the spot if in his judgment the dog cannot be safely captured without causing harm to the officer or the public the officer shall not be held liable for the loss of the dog 7 if the owner or keeper of the dog that has been designated dangerous is unwilling or unable to comply with the regulations of this subsection d for keeping such dog then he must have the animal humanely euthanized by the animal control department or a licensed veterinarian after a holding period of ten days all costs shall be borne by the owner    3182008 eff 412008 state law reference authority to regulate restrict or prohibit the possession of dangerous animals gs 160a187 notification of injury to animal required it shall be unlawful for any person injuring an animal to fail to immediately notify the owner or keeper of the animal or an animal control officer humane society or the police department of the city  cruelty to animals a it shall be unlawful for any person to molest torture torment deprive of necessary sustenance cruelly beat needlessly mutilate or kill wound injure poison abandon or subject any animal to conditions detrimental to its health or general welfare or to cause or procure such action the terms torture and torment shall be held to include every act omission or neglect whereby unjustifiable physical pain suffering or death is caused or permitted such terms shall not be construed to prohibit lawful taking of animals under the jurisdiction and regulation of the wildlife resources commission  nor to prohibit the animal control officer or persons duly authorized from destroying dangerous unwanted or injured animals in a humane manner b it shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to fail to provide his animal with proper shelter and protection from the weather sufficient and wholesome food and water to keep his animal in good health and comfort the opportunity for vigorous daily exercise veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering and humane care and treatment c it shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale barter or give away within the city baby chickens baby ducklings other fowl or rabbits under eight weeks of age as pets toys premiums or novelties this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the sale or display of baby chickens ducklings other fowl or rabbits in proper facilities by breeders or stores engaged in the business of selling such fowl or rabbits for purposes other than for pets or novelties d it shall be unlawful to color dye stain or otherwise change the natural color of baby chickens other fowl or rabbits e it shall be unlawful for any person to tether any fowl f it shall be unlawful for any person to incite procure or cause any animal fight within the corporate limits of the city  state law reference cruelty to animals gs 14360  power of city to define and prohibit abuse of animals gs 160a182  protection of animals gs ch 19a luring enticing seizing molesting or teasing it shall be unlawful for any person to entice or lure any animal out of an enclosure or off the property of its owner or keeper or to seize molest or tease any animal while the animal is held or controlled by its owner or keeper or while the animal is on the property of its owner or keeper  restraint of dogs a when a dog is on the property of its owner or keeper and is not within a secure enclosure it shall be under the direct control of and obedient to the owner or keeper at all other times when a dog is on the property of its owner or keeper it shall be kept within a secure enclosure including a fenced in area or electronic fence house or other building of sufficient strength and height to prevent the dog from escaping from such enclosure provided the owner or keeper may for a period not to exceed one hour every 24 hours allow the dog to be tethered or chained to a stationary object or pole as long as the dog is provided with sufficient water and nourishment all dogs off of the property of its owner or keeper shall be controlled by means of a leash and under the direct control of and obedient to the owners or keepers command b noncompliance with any of the provisions of subsection a of this section may result in the impoundment of the animal at any time or may result in a fine of $10000 or both with respect to any dog found in violation of subsection a for a second time animal control shall have the authority to require that the owner thereof have the dog spayed or neutered by a licensed veterinarian within twenty 20 days all costs of such spaying or neutering shall be the responsibility of the owner failure to comply with any directive to have the dog spayed or neutered shall result in and additional civil penalty of $10000 c dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the course of law enforcement activities are exempt from this section    3182008 eff 412008 confinement of female cats and dogs in heat when any female cat or dog is in heat the owner of such animal shall confine the cat or dog in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that the animal will not be in contact with another cat or dog or create a nuisance by attracting males with respect to any female cat or dog is found in violation of this section animal control shall have the authority to require that the owner thereof have the cat or dog spayed within 20 days by a licensed veterinarian all costs shall be borne by the owner this section shall not be construed to prohibit the intentional breeding of animals within an enclosed area on the premises of the owner of the animal being bred    3182008 the time application is made for such license the owner shall state whether the license is for a cat or dog the breed color and sex of the animal and shall submit proof that the animal has been immunized b upon payment of the license fee the owner shall be issued a tag for each cat or dog licensed the owner shall provide each cat or dog with a collar to which the current license tag must be affixed and shall ensure that the tag and collar are constantly worn by each cat or dog at all times except as otherwise provided in this chapter c the annual license fee shall be set from time to time by the city council and on file in the city clerks office and shall be payable between january 1 and february 15 of each year d in addition to all other penalties prescribed by law a cat or dog is subject to impoundment in accordance with the provisions of this chapter if the cat or dog is found not to be wearing a currently valid license tag the provisions of this section shall not apply to any dog being kept in any governmental facility veterinary hospital licensed commercial animal establishment or seeing eye or service dogs properly trained to assist blind and other disabled persons or law enforcement animals e it shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to obtain a license tag for his cat or dog within 30 days of moving into the city or acquiring the animal f if ownership of a currently licensed cat or dog is transferred the new owner may have the current license transferred to his name upon payment to the consumer billing department of a fee as established by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerks office g replacement license tags may be obtained from the consumer billing department upon payment of a fee as established by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerks office h after written warning has been given to the owner or keeper of an unimmunized or unlicensed animal notifying such owner or keeper of their failure to license andor vaccinate their animal the animal control officer may issue a citation to the pet owner the penalty associated with the issuance of a citation shall be set from time to time by the city council and a schedule of such penalties is on file and available in the city clerks office  state law reference animal taxes gs 160a212 strays a it shall be unlawful for any person in the city to knowingly and intentionally harbor feed keep in possession by confinement or otherwise allow to remain on his property any animal which does not belong to him unless within 72 hours from the time such animal came into his possession he has notified the animal control officer or duly authorized person b it shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to surrender any such stray animal to the animal control officer or duly authorized person upon demand  nondomestic animal nuisance notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary if any nondomestic animal or group of nondomestic animals become a nuisance the animal control officer may take whatever measures are necessary to abate the nuisance including but not limited to requiring the citizen to take preventive measures trap and remove trap to destroy or destroy such animals the animal control officer may authorize in writing other persons to carry out the provisions of this section and such persons shall work under the control and supervision of the animal control officer any citizen of the city may petition the animal control officer for relief from any nuisance created by a nondomestic animal or group of nondomestic animals and the animal control officer shall forthwith investigate the situation and take whatever action is appropriate to abate the nuisance if the animal control officer fails to act within ten days after receipt of the petition or if the action taken by the animal control officer is ineffective the petitioner may then file the petition with the city manager and the city manager is authorized to take whatever action is appropriate to abate the nuisance and he is authorized to assume all the powers and duties conferred upon the animal control officer in this section no actions taken under this section shall be in violation of any state or federal wildlife laws or regulations  violations  penalties a the violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor and any person convicted of such violation shall be punished as provided in section 110 each days violation of this chapter is a separate offense payment of a fine imposed in criminal proceedings pursuant to this subsection does not relieve a person of his liability for fees imposed under this chapter b in addition enforcement of this chapter may be by appropriate equitable remedial injunction or order of abatement issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to gs 160a175 c in addition to or in lieu of impounding a currently licensed dog found running at large the animal control officer or his agent may issue a notice of violation of this chapter to the known owner of such dog such notice shall impose upon the owner of the dog a penalty as established by the city council which penalty shall be on file in the office of the city clerk the notice of violation referred to in this subsection may be delivered in person or mailed to the person violating the provisions of this chapter  domesticated animals at vacant residences or structures it shall be unlawful for any person owning or having possession charge custody or control of any domesticated animal to allow the animal to be confined at a vacant residence or structure for a period of more than 14 days for the purposes of this section a residence or structure shall be deemed vacant if there is either no electrical or water service to the same or the same is determined to be uninhabitable by the building inspector at any time during this 14day period if the animal is not adequately and properly cared for or is otherwise subjected to conditions detrimental to its health and general welfare it shall be deemed abandoned according to state law and shall be seized impounded and confined in an animal shelter in a humane manner subject to the terms and conditions of article ii of this chapter  7172007 secs 426460  reserved article ii  impoundment generally a any animal which appears to be lost stray or unwanted or not wearing a currently valid license tag or rabies vaccination tag as required by state law or this chapter or not under restraint in violation of this chapter may be seized impounded and confined in an animal shelter in a humane manner b impoundment of such an animal shall not relieve the owner or keeper of such animal from any penalty which may be imposed for a violation of this chapter  notice to owner or keeper a upon impounding an animal notice of impoundment shall be posted for a minimum of 72 hours beginning with the time the animal enters the animal shelter or until the animal is disposed of reasonable effort shall be made to identify the owner or keeper and inform the owner or keeper of the conditions whereby the animal may be redeemed b such notice shall be prominently displayed on a bulletin board at the animal shelter and the time and place of the taking of the animal together with the time and date of posting the notice shall be stated in such notice c in the case of impoundment of a duly licensed dog not later than three days after impounding the dog the animal control officer or his agent shall attempt to notify the registered owner of the dog by telephone or personal contact should such notification be unsuccessful the animal control officer or his agent shall mail a certified letter to the address indicated on the license tag application if the certified letter is returned to the city as undeliverable to the address stated on the license application the city may be relieved of all responsibility of contacting the owner of the dog  redemption by owner or keeper  fees a the owner or keeper of an animal impounded under this article may redeem the animal and regain possession thereof within 72 hours after notice of impoundment is posted as required by this article by complying with all applicable provisions of this article and paying any applicable fees b the consumer billing department shall charge and collect fees from owners who redeem their animals for the apprehension notice feeding and care of such animals such fees shall be established by the city council from time to time and are on file at the animal shelter and in the office of the city clerk c the fees referred to in subsection b of this section do not include any penalty for a violation of any provision of this chapter nor do they include any charges for licenses or inoculations that may be required of the owner  redemption of unvaccinated dogs and cats a unless proof of a current rabies vaccination can be furnished every person who redeems a dog or cat at the animal shelter will be given a proof of rabies vaccination notice at the time of such redemption the notice will be marked with a date and state the maximum time limit allowed to take the dog or cat to the veterinarian of such persons choice for rabies vaccination the time limit for dogs and cats four months of age and older will be 72 hours excluding sundays and holidays the time limit for puppies and kittens under four months of age will vary according to their age b the proof of rabies vaccination notice will be completed by the veterinarian and returned to the animal control officer by the animal owner or keeper c payment of the rabies vaccination required by this section will be the responsibility of the person redeeming or adopting the animal  disposition of unredeemed animals a if an impounded animal is not redeemed by the owner or keeper within the period prescribed in section 462 it may be destroyed in a humane manner or shall become the property of the animal shelter and offered for adoption to a responsible adult who is willing to comply with this article b immediately prior to the euthanization of any duly licensed dog it shall be the responsibility of the animal control officer or his agent to certify to the city manager that the notice to the owner required by this article has been made pursuant to the provisions of section 462c  adoption or destruction of animals surrendered by their owners any animal surrendered by its owner to the animal control officer may be immediately turned over to the animal shelter for adoption or humanely destroyed by the animal control officer the waiting periods provided in section 462 shall not apply to immediate adoption or destruction in this section  destruction of animals which cannot be seized by reasonable means notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter an animal which cannot be seized by reasonable means may be humanely destroyed by or upon order
